010package imagingbook.lib.math;
011
012//import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
013import org.apache.commons.math3.stat.correlation.Covariance;
014
015/**
016 * Utility class defines a few statistical methods.
017 * @author WB
018 *
019 */
020public abstract class Statistics {
021        
022        /**
023         * Calculates the covariance matrix for a sequence of sample vectors.
024         * Takes a sequence of n data samples, each of dimension m.
025         * The data element samples[i][j] refers to the j-th component
026         * of sample i. No statistical bias correction is applied.
027         * @param samples Array of m-dimensional vectors (double[n][m]).
028         * @return The covariance matrix (of dimension double{m][m]).
029         */
030        public static double[][] covarianceMatrix(double[][] samples) {
031                return covarianceMatrix(samples, false);
032        }
033        
034        /**
035         * Calculates the covariance matrix for a sequence of sample vectors.
036         * Takes a sequence of n data samples, each of dimension m.
037         * The data element samples[i][j] refers to the j-th component
038         * of sample i. No statistical bias correction is applied.
039         * @param samples Array of m-dimensional vectors (double[n][m]).
040         * @param biasCorrect If {@code true}, statistical bias correction is applied.
041         * @return The covariance matrix (of dimension double{m][m]).
042         */
043        public static double[][] covarianceMatrix(double[][] samples, boolean biasCorrect) {
044                Covariance cov = new Covariance(samples, biasCorrect);
045                return cov.getCovarianceMatrix().getData();
046        }
047        
048//      /** 
049//       * example from UTICS-C Appendix:
050//       * N = 4 samples
051//       * K = 3 dimensions
052//       * @param args ignored
053//       */
054//      public static void main(String[] args) {
055//              
056//              boolean BIAS_CORRECT = false;
057//              
058//              // example: n = 4 samples of dimension m = 3:
059//              // samples[i][j], i = column (sample index), j = row (dimension index).
060//              double[][] samples = { 
061//                              {75, 37, 12},   // i = 0
062//                              {41, 27, 20},   // i = 1
063//                              {93, 81, 11},   // i = 2
064//                              {12, 48, 52}    // i = 3
065//              };
066//              
067//              // covariance matrix Cov (3x3)
068//              double[][] cov = covarianceMatrix(samples, BIAS_CORRECT);
069//              System.out.println("cov = \n" + Matrix.toString(cov));
070//              
071//              System.out.println();
072//              
073//              double[][] icov = Matrix.inverse(cov);
074//              System.out.println("icov = \n" + Matrix.toString(icov));
075//              
076//              System.out.println();
077//              
078//              double trace = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(cov).getTrace();
079//              System.out.println("trace(cov) = " + trace);
080//              double Fnorm = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(cov).getFrobeniusNorm();
081//              System.out.println("Fnorm(cov) = " + Fnorm);
082//      }
083        
084/* Results (bias-corrected):
085cov = 
086{{1296.250, 442.583, -627.250}, 
087{442.583, 550.250, -70.917}, 
088{-627.250, -70.917, 370.917}}
089
090icov = 
091{{0.024, -0.014, 0.038}, 
092{-0.014, 0.011, -0.022}, 
093{0.038, -0.022, 0.063}}
094*/
095        
096/* verified with Mathematica
097X1 = {75, 37, 12}; X2 = {41, 27, 20}; X3 = {93, 81, 11}; X4 = {12, 48, 52};
098samples = {X1, X2, X3, X4}
099N[Covariance[samples]]
100-> {{1296.25, 442.583, -627.25}, {442.583, 550.25, -70.9167}, {-627.25, -70.9167, 370.917}}
101*/
102        
103/* Results (NON bias-corrected):
104cov = 
105{{972.188, 331.938, -470.438}, 
106{331.938, 412.688, -53.188}, 
107{-470.438, -53.188, 278.188}}
108
109icov = {{0.032, -0.019, 0.051}, 
110{-0.019, 0.014, -0.030}, 
111{0.051, -0.030, 0.083}}
112*/
113
114}
